key_title: Key to the species of Ranunculus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Ranunculaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Ranunculaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Ranunculaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Submerged aquatic with leaves divided into numerous filiform segments, the segments not arranged within a single plane; petals white; achenes transversely ridged
Terrestrial herbs, or, if aquatic and with divided leaves, the segments broader and arranged in 1 plane; petals usually yellow; achenes various, but not transversely ridged
Plants annual; achenes often tuberculate
Plants perennial, but leaves often winter-deciduous, resprouting from a persistent rootstock; achenes smooth or ridged but not conspicuously tuberculate
Plants tufted, sometimes with slightly tuberiform roots; petals usually obovate to broadly obovate
Plants with rhizomes or stolons; petals often oblong or narrowly obovate
Leaves pinnately divided into rather distant linear, subterete segments; deeply rhizomic herb of higher alps, flowers large, appearing soon after snow-melt
Leaves entire or variously lobed to pinnatisect, segments usually flat
Petals less than 5 mm wide
Petals relatively large, 5–10 mm wide; nectary lobe broadly cuneate; vigorous weeds
Leaves glabrous to pilose, often slightly variegated; pedicels grooved; receptacle pubescent; common weed of ditches and moist roadsides, usually spreading by above-ground stolons
Leaves rather densely pubescent (at least beneath), not variegated; pedicels terete; receptacle glabrous; plants with coarse subterranean rhizomes
Nectary lacking a lobe, appearing as a crescentic bracket
Nectary with a distinct lobe, often the lateral margins partly or wholly fused to the petal and forming a narrow pocket
Leaves simple
Leaves dissected
Leaves pinnatisect; flower usually white; confined to shallow pools in alps
Leaves trilobed to palmately divided; flower pale yellow; widespread
All leaves trilobed with more or less cuneate segments, these sometimes toothed or shallowly lobed
Adult leaves palmately lobed or trilobed, with oblong to linear segments
Petals c. 3–5 mm long; flowering stems commonly c. 5 cm high or less
Petals 5.5–12 mm long; flowering stems commonly 10 cm high or more
Mature achene with lateral ridges; free part of nectary lobe truncate or emarginate
Mature achene not obviously ridged on sides, often with a broad dorsal thickening; free part of nectary lobe obtuse
Achenes usually more than 20 per head, each c. 2 mm long, with c. 6 narrow ridges on the sides; plants typically at least 30 cm high
Achenes fewer than 20 per head, each 2.5–3 mm long, with 2 or 3 rather broad ridges on the sides; plants rarely taller than c. 20 cm
Leaf-segments slender, linear, c. 1mm wide; sepals glabrous or very sparsely pilose; plants often (at least partially) submerged
Leaf-segments 2 mm wide or wider; sepals hispid; usually on seasonally wet ground but not submerged
Leaf lamina 5–13 cm diam.; petals 8–16, 5–13 mm long; achenes 2–4 mm long (excluding beak)
Leaf lamina 1–3.5(–5) cm diam.; petals 5–7, 4.5–7 mm long; achenes 1.5–1.8 mm long (excluding beak)
Leaves pinnate or pinnatisect; alpine plants
Leaves entire or ternately lobed or divided; alpine or lowland plants
Leaf-segments relatively broad, never linear
Leaf-segments oblong to terete
Leaf-segments terete or semi-terete; flowers large (20 mm diam. or more), bright yellow, appearing soon after snow-melt
Leaf-segments linear but more or less flat; flowers usually white, less than 20 mm diam.; plants typically of shallow pools or depressions
Sepals reflexed at anthesis; achenes sometimes with a row of stiff appressed hairs along the dorsal margin
Sepals spreading at anthesis; achenes glabrous
Achene beak less than 1 mm long, strongly recurved
Achene beak 1.2 mm long or more, straight or arching with a recoiled tip
Achenes very plump, virtually flat dorsally; roots often somewhat tuberous
Achenes more or less lenticular, acute or obtusely angled dorsally
Nectary lobe cuneate or obovate, more or less truncate, widest at the apex; flowers usually 2–several on branched stems; roots fibrous or fleshy-tuberous; lowlands to subalps
Nectary lobe oblong to obovate, widest near the middle; flowers solitary on unbranched stems (rarely with 2–3 flowers in R. graniticola); roots fibrous; subalpine to alpine
Achene biconvex, obovate, smooth on sides; beak slender; widespread, mostly in forested areas, common in east
Achene flattish with thickened margin, rather angular, often wider than long and ridged on sides; beak rather stout; inhabiting swamps and depressions in west
Hairs on stems and petioles spreading
Hairs on stems and petioles appressed

Leaves ovate to spathulate, entire or shortly and broadly 3-toothed at apex; upper surface with numerous rigid semi-appressed to spreading hairs; petioles to c. 10 cm long (often much less); nectary lobe minute or absent
Leaves shallowly to deeply 3-toothed, or ternately or biternately lobed, upper surface with scattered short appressed hairs; petioles commonly longer than 10 cm; nectary lobe oblong to obovate
Leaves shallowly to deeply 3-toothed or lobed with segments usually directed forwards, entire, toothed or again 3-lobed; ultimate segments lanceolate or broad-lanceolate
Leaves ternate with segments widely spreading, ternately or biternately lobed; ultimate segments linear-lanceolate
Leaves simple throughout, narrow-elliptic
At least the lower leaves toothed or lobed to some degree
Fruiting head more or less cylindric; achenes plump, without coarse bristles or tubercles, 70-100 or more per head
Fruiting head more or less globoid; achenes strongly flattened, usually with bristles or tubercles, fewer than 50 per head
Flowers 5 mm diam. or more, petals conspicuous; receptacle hairy
Flowers less than 5 mm diam., petals inconspicuous; receptacle glabrous
Mature achene 7 mm long or more; at least the basal leaves crenate to shallowly lobed
Mature achene (including beak) 2–3 mm long; leaves deeply lobed
Achenes entirely smooth or with scattered, low obtuse tubercles toward the margin
Achenes evenly covered with short acute tubercles
Achenes orbicular, very thin and often twisted at maturity; tubercles largely confined to central part of achene faces
Achenes ovate, strongly or weakly biconvex, but not twisting at maturity; tubercles evenly distributed or achene faces smooth

Achenes (including beak) 2.5 mm long or more; petals shortly exceeding sepals; nectary attached about one-third of petal length from base; at least the lower leaves almost circular in outline and shallowly lobed
Achenes (including beak) barely 2 mm long; petals shorter than sepals; nectary attached about half petal length from base; leaves usually deeply divided

Achenes lenticular, either smooth and glabrous, or largely covered with appressed hairs, each longer than the diameter of its subtending tubercle; beak of achene usually less than 25% total length of achene
Achenes flattish, with scattered tubercles having short hooked bristles that are no longer than the diameter of the tubercle; beak of achene usually 30–50% total length of achene
